name: Bash
description: Executes the given shell command in the user's default shell. Important notes: 1. Directory verification - If the command will create new directories or files, first use the list_directory tool to verify the parent directory exists. 2. Working directory - If no cwd parameter is provided, the working directory is the first workspace root folder. 3. Multiple independent commands - Do NOT chain multiple independent commands with ; or && on Windows. Do NOT use the single & operator to run background processes. 4. Escaping & Quoting - ALWAYS quote file paths with double quotes. 5. Truncated output - Only the last 50000 characters of the output will be returned. 6. Stateless environment - Setting an environment variable or using cd only impacts a single command. 7. Cross platform support - When Windows, use powershell commands instead of Linux commands. 8. User visibility - The user is shown the terminal output. 9. Avoid interactive commands - Do NOT use commands that require interactive input.

amp.description: Executes the given shell command in the user's default shell. Important notes: 1. Multiple independent commands - Do NOT chain multiple independent commands with ; or && on Windows. Do NOT use the single & operator to run background processes. 4. Escaping & Quoting - ALWAYS quote file paths with double quotes. 5. Truncated output - Only the last 50000 characters of the output will be returned. 6. Stateless environment - Setting an environment variable or using cd only impacts a single command. 7. Cross platform support - When Windows, use powershell commands instead of Linux commands. 8. User visibility - The user is shown the terminal output. 9. Avoid interactive commands - Do NOT use commands that require interactive input.

cwd.description: Absolute path to a directory where the command will be executed (must be absolute, not relative)

name: codebase_search_agent
description: Intelligently search your codebase with an agent that has access to: list_directory, Grep, glob, Read. The agent acts like your personal search assistant. It's ideal for complex, multi-step search tasks where you need to find code based on functionality or concepts rather than exact matches. WHEN TO USE: When searching for high-level concepts like authentication headers or error handling. When you need to combine multiple search techniques. When looking for connections between different parts of the codebase. WHEN NOT TO USE: When you know the exact file path - use Read directly. When looking for specific symbols or exact strings - use glob or Grep.

amp.description: Intelligently search your codebase with an agent that has access to: list_directory, Grep, glob, Read. The agent acts like your personal search assistant. It's ideal for complex, multi-step search tasks where you need to find code based on functionality or concepts rather than exact matches. WHEN TO USE: When searching for high-level concepts like authentication headers or error handling. When you need to combine multiple search techniques. When looking for connections between different parts of the codebase. WHEN NOT TO USE: When you know the exact file path - use Read directly. When looking for specific symbols or exact strings - use glob or Grep.

query.description: The search query describing to the agent what it should. Be specific and include technical terms, file types, or expected code patterns to help the agent find relevant code.

name: create_file
description: Create or overwrite a file in the workspace. Use this tool when you want to create a new file with the given content, or when you want to replace the contents of an existing file. Prefer this tool over edit_file when you want to overwrite the entire contents of a file.

amp.description: Create or overwrite a file in the workspace. Use this tool when you want to create a new file with the given content, or when you want to replace the contents of an existing file. Prefer this tool over edit_file when you want to overwrite the entire contents of a file.

name: edit_file
description: Make edits to a text file. Replaces old_str with new_str in the given file. Returns a git-style diff showing the changes made as formatted markdown, along with the line range of the changed content. The file specified by path MUST exist. If you need to create a new file, use create_file instead. old_str MUST exist in the file. old_str and new_str MUST be different from each other. Set replace_all to true to replace all occurrences of old_str in the file.

amp.description: Make edits to a text file. Replaces old_str with new_str in the given file. Returns a git-style diff showing the changes made as formatted markdown, along with the line range of the changed content. The file specified by path MUST exist. If you need to create a new file, use create_file instead. old_str MUST exist in the file. old_str and new_str MUST be different from each other. Set replace_all to true to replace all occurrences of old_str in the file.

path.description: The absolute path to the file (must be absolute, not relative). File must exist. ALWAYS generate this argument first.

old_str.description: Text to search for. Must match exactly.

replace_all.description: Set to true to replace all matches of old_str. Else, old_str must be an unique match.

name: glob
description: Fast file pattern matching tool that works with any codebase size. Use this tool to find files by name patterns across your codebase. It returns matching file paths sorted by recent modification time. WHEN TO USE: When you need to find specific file types, when you want to find files in specific directories, when you need to explore the codebase structure quickly, when you need to find recently modified files. File pattern syntax: **/*.js for all JavaScript files, src/**/*.ts for all TypeScript files under src, *.json for all JSON files in current directory, **/*test* for all files with test in name.

amp.description: Fast file pattern matching tool that works with any codebase size. Use this tool to find files by name patterns across your codebase. It returns matching file paths sorted by recent modification time. WHEN TO USE: When you need to find specific file types, when you want to find files in specific directories, when you need to explore the codebase structure quickly, when you need to find recently modified files. File pattern syntax: **/*.js for all JavaScript files, src/**/*.ts for all TypeScript files under src, *.json for all JSON files in current directory, **/*test* for all files with test in name.

name: Grep
description: Search for exact text patterns in files using ripgrep, a fast keyword search tool. WHEN TO USE: When you need to find exact text matches like variable names, function calls, or specific strings. When you know the precise pattern you're looking for including regex patterns. When you want to quickly locate all occurrences of a specific term. WHEN NOT TO USE: For semantic or conceptual searches - use codebase_search instead. For finding code that implements certain functionality without knowing exact terms - use codebase_search. SEARCH PATTERN TIPS: Use regex patterns for more powerful searches. Ensure you use Rust-style regex. Add context to your search with surrounding terms. Use the path parameter to narrow your search to specific directories.

amp.description: Search for exact text patterns in files using ripgrep, a fast keyword search tool. WHEN TO USE: When you need to find exact text matches like variable names, function calls, or specific strings. When you know the precise pattern you're looking for including regex patterns. When you want to quickly locate all occurrences of a specific term. WHEN NOT TO USE: For semantic or conceptual searches - use codebase_search instead. For finding code that implements certain functionality without knowing exact terms - use codebase_search. SEARCH PATTERN TIPS: Use regex patterns for more powerful searches. Ensure you use Rust-style regex. Add context to your search with surrounding terms. Use the path parameter to narrow your search to specific directories.

path.description: The file or directory path to search in. Cannot be used with glob.

glob.description: The glob pattern to search for. Cannot be used with path.

name: list_directory
description: List the files in the workspace in a given directory. Use the glob tool for filtering files by pattern.

amp.description: List the files in the workspace in a given directory. Use the glob tool for filtering files by pattern.

name: mermaid
description: Renders a Mermaid diagram from the provided code. PROACTIVELY USE DIAGRAMS when they would better convey information than prose alone. You should create diagrams WITHOUT being explicitly asked in these scenarios: When explaining system architecture or component relationships, when describing workflows or data flows, when explaining algorithms or complex processes, when illustrating class hierarchies, when showing state transitions. Diagrams are especially valuable for visualizing: Application architecture, API interactions, component hierarchies, state machines, sequence and timing of operations, decision trees. STYLING: When defining custom classDefs, always define fill color, stroke color, and text color explicitly. IMPORTANT!!! Use DARK fill colors with light stroke and text colors.

amp.description: Renders a Mermaid diagram from the provided code. PROACTIVELY USE DIAGRAMS when they would better convey information than prose alone. You should create diagrams WITHOUT being explicitly asked in these scenarios: When explaining system architecture or component relationships, when describing workflows or data flows, when explaining algorithms or complex processes, when illustrating class hierarchies, when showing state transitions. Diagrams are especially valuable for visualizing: Application architecture, API interactions, component hierarchies, state machines, sequence and timing of operations, decision trees. STYLING: When defining custom classDefs, always define fill color, stroke color, and text color explicitly. IMPORTANT!!! Use DARK fill colors with light stroke and text colors.

code.description: The Mermaid diagram code to render (DO NOT override with custom colors or other styles)

name: oracle
description: Consult the Oracle - an AI advisor powered by OpenAI's o3 reasoning model that can plan, review, and provide expert guidance. The Oracle has access to the following tools: list_directory, Read, Grep, glob, web_search, read_web_page. The Oracle acts as your senior engineering advisor. WHEN TO USE: Code reviews and architecture feedback, finding bugs in multiple files, planning complex implementations, analyzing code quality, answering complex technical questions. WHEN NOT TO USE: Simple file reading or searching tasks, codebase searches (use codebase_search_agent), web browsing (use read_web_page or web_search), basic code modifications.

task.description: The task or question you want the Oracle to help with. Be specific about what kind of guidance, review, or planning you need.

name: Read
description: Read a file from the file system. If the file doesn't exist, an error is returned. The path parameter must be an absolute path. By default, this tool returns the first 1000 lines. To read more, call it multiple times with different read_ranges. Use the Grep tool to find specific content in large files. If you are unsure of the correct file path, use the glob tool. The contents are returned with each line prefixed by its line number. This tool can read images and present them visually. When possible, call this tool in parallel for all files you will want to read.

amp.description: Read a file from the file system. If the file doesn't exist, an error is returned. The path parameter must be an absolute path. By default, this tool returns the first 1000 lines. To read more, call it multiple times with different read_ranges. Use the Grep tool to find specific content in large files. If you are unsure of the correct file path, use the glob tool. The contents are returned with each line prefixed by its line number. This tool can read images and present them visually. When possible, call this tool in parallel for all files you will want to read.

path.description: The absolute path to the file to read (must be absolute, not relative).

read_range.description: An array of two integers specifying the start and end line numbers to view. Line numbers are 1-indexed. Examples: [500, 700], [700, 1400]

name: read_mcp_resource
description: Read a resource from an MCP (Model Context Protocol) server. This tool allows you to read resources that are exposed by MCP servers. Resources can be files, database entries, or any other data. PARAMETERS: server - The name or identifier of the MCP server, uri - The URI of the resource to read. WHEN TO USE: When user prompt mentions MCP resource. EXAMPLES: Read a file from MCP file server, read a database record from MCP database server.

amp.description: Read a resource from an MCP (Model Context Protocol) server. This tool allows you to read resources that are exposed by MCP servers. Resources can be files, database entries, or any other data. PARAMETERS: server - The name or identifier of the MCP server, uri - The URI of the resource to read. WHEN TO USE: When user prompt mentions MCP resource. EXAMPLES: Read a file from MCP file server, read a database record from MCP database server.

server.description: The name or identifier of the MCP server to read from

uri.description: The URI of the resource to read

name: read_web_page
description: Read and analyze the contents of a web page from a given URL. When only the url parameter is set, it returns the contents converted to Markdown. If the raw parameter is set, it returns the raw HTML. If a prompt is provided, the contents and prompt are passed to a model to extract or summarize information. Prefer using the prompt parameter over the raw parameter. WHEN TO USE: When you need to extract information from a web page, when user shares URLs to documentation or specifications, when user asks you to build something similar to what's at a URL, when you need to fetch and read text content. WHEN NOT TO USE: When visual elements are important, when navigation is required, when you need to interact with the webpage.

amp.description: Read and analyze the contents of a web page from a given URL. When only the url parameter is set, it returns the contents converted to Markdown. If the raw parameter is set, it returns the raw HTML. If a prompt is provided, the contents and prompt are passed to a model to extract or summarize information. Prefer using the prompt parameter over the raw parameter. WHEN TO USE: When you need to extract information from a web page, when user shares URLs to documentation or specifications, when user asks you to build something similar to what's at a URL, when you need to fetch and read text content. WHEN NOT TO USE: When visual elements are important, when navigation is required, when you need to interact with the webpage.

url.description: The URL of the web page to read

prompt.description: Optional prompt for AI-powered analysis using small and fast model. When provided, the tool uses this prompt to analyze the markdown content.

raw.description: Return raw HTML content instead of converting to markdown. Not used when prompt is provided.

name: Task
description: Perform a task (a sub-task of the user's overall task) using a sub-agent that has access to: list_directory, Grep, glob, Read, Bash, edit_file, create_file, format_file, read_web_page, get_diagnostics, web_search, codebase_search_agent. WHEN TO USE: When you need to perform complex multi-step tasks, when you need to run an operation that will produce a lot of output, when you are making changes across many layers of an application after planning, when the user asks you to launch an agent. WHEN NOT TO USE: When performing a single logical task, when reading a single file (use Read), when performing text search (use Grep), when editing a single file (use edit_file). HOW TO USE: Run multiple sub-agents concurrently if tasks are independent. You will not see individual steps. Include all necessary context and detailed plan. Tell the sub-agent how to verify its work.

amp.description: Perform a task (a sub-task of the user's overall task) using a sub-agent that has access to: list_directory, Grep, glob, Read, Bash, edit_file, create_file, format_file, read_web_page, get_diagnostics, web_search, codebase_search_agent. WHEN TO USE: When you need to perform complex multi-step tasks, when you need to run an operation that will produce a lot of output, when you are making changes across many layers of an application after planning, when the user asks you to launch an agent. WHEN NOT TO USE: When performing a single logical task, when reading a single file (use Read), when performing text search (use Grep), when editing a single file (use edit_file). HOW TO USE: Run multiple sub-agents concurrently if tasks are independent. You will not see individual steps. Include all necessary context and detailed plan. Tell the sub-agent how to verify its work.

prompt.description: The task for the agent to perform. Be specific about what needs to be done and include any relevant context.

description.description: A very short description of the task that can be displayed to the user.
